result.execSummary:
The defendant Donald E. Erdman was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Failure to pay any part of the fine or court costs in full by the due date will result in 1 day jail for each $25 left unpaid.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Donald E. Erdman

DNA Proof of Submission

DKJ began clerking:  Defendant appeared with counsel SPD Paul Fredrickson.  Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  SPD Fredrickson states charge be amended to misdemeanor DC, domestic abuse, with enhancer stricken; 10 days jail plus costs.  Information previously filed amending charge.  Court reviews charges/possible penalties.  Plea to Count 1 in Information which was filed 1/20/15 is guilty.  Court reviews elements/guilty plea questionnaire/rights.  Court makes finding the defendant understands the proceedings, waives his rights & enters his plea freely, voluntarily, and intelligently and finds him guilty.  Victim is present and has ADA Inlow read a statement and also makes a statement in addition.  JMM completed: State recommended 60 days jail, to report immediately with credit for 3 days.  Attorney Fredrickson recommended 10 days with credit for 3 days, to start immediately.  Defendant elected to exercise his right to allocution.  Court ordered 75 days jail to start immediately.  Credit for 3 days.  CC.  DNA sample.
Plea/sentencing hearing at 04-13-2015 10:30 am

Finds defendant has freely, voluntarily, and intelligently waived his right to a preliminary hearing.  Information filed with court.
